awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Connected Barriers: Vehicle to Barrier Communication and Networking for Single-Vehicle Crash Safety
awd_abstract_narration:
More than half of fatal vehicle crashes in the US today are "run-off-road" (RoR) crashes and roadside barriers are the last means of mitigating their severity. Yet, vehicles of tomorrow are slated to operate on roadside infrastructure designed decades ago. This project aims to bridge this gap by establishing wireless connectivity between vehicles and roadside barriers by developing a novel vehicle to barrier (V2B) communication and networking paradigm called connected barriers (CBs). CBs will (1) complement on-board sensor technologies and existing physical barriers, (2) avoid RoR crashes, (3) minimize the severity of a crash when it is inevitable, and (4) help develop mutual collaborations between the roadside safety and vehicular communication and networking communities, which will lead to robust technology solutions. Based on Department of Transportation's value of a statistical life estimate in 2014, the societal cost of a crash is $9.4 million per fatality, with approximately 10,000 fatal ROR crashes each year. With widespread implementation, this research project could reduce fatal and non-fatal crash rates by up to 70%, which could save as many as 8,000 lives per year in the U.S. alone and billions of dollars in economic losses. This project supports 2 graduate students and its results will be incorporated into several courses at UNL and OSU. Insights from the project results will help establish collaborative efforts to educate both industry and academia in Nebraska and Ohio. 

To realize the CB vision, the project explores three main threads: (1) the foundations of V2B communication will be established through analysis of wireless channel characteristics in field measurements, actual car-crash tests, and channel model development. (2) to enable reliable control reactions, very high-fidelity barrier-assisted vehicle localization and vehicle-barrier synchronization solutions will be developed. (3) novel communication algorithms and protocols will be developed to disseminate periodic information about barrier and road conditions, and to facilitate real-time information exchange during upcoming RoR events, with an eye towards coexistence with existing communication standards. The developed solutions will be evaluated through encroachment and vehicle crash experiments in the Midwest Roadside Safety Facility, and system evaluations on low-volume suburban and rural road segments in collaboration with the Village of Eagle, Nebraska, and Nebraska's Cass County. Finally, a multi-time-scale simulation platform will be integrated by including empirical measurements of the wireless channel, vehicle and barrier dynamics, traffic dynamics, and communication and network dynamics to provide effective evaluation tools of the CB paradigm

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to analyze wireless channel characteristics, integrate advanced vehicle-barrier technology, and develop real-time communication algorithms for road events. Experiments are performed by experts in roadside safety, wireless communication, and networking. Improved vehicle safety, reduced cost for state departments of transportation (DOTs), improved traffic flow, and better traffic monitoring data are expected outcomes. Accordingly, state DOTs will be better-suited to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of safety treatments under reduced ROR crash risk and focus resources on the most vulnerable roadside assets. 

We have conducted 24 different real-world crash experiments with the collaboration of MwRSF, where vehicles collide with barriers while equipped with different antennas at various heights. Data collected is analyzed for key performance metrics such as RSS, SINR, EVM, PE, BER, and coherence time. An improved error correction mechanism is used for OFDM signal data to reduce missing packets, leveraging known bitstreams for improved signal demodulation.

We study the V2B channel model by analyzing 3 metrics: path loss, RMS delay spread, and RMS Doppler spread. Two types of experiments were conducted- static open-space and V2B crash tests. Empirical values were obtained and analyzed with mathematical models to explain the impact of various factors. A lognormal RMS delay spread and RMS Doppler spread model were derived to depict the impact of vehicle shape, barrier type, and antenna height. Correction procedures for CSI calculation were analyzed and model parameters were categorized based on vehicle and barrier design and antenna deployment height. These parameters can be used as a guideline for vehicle and barrier design and antenna deployment. This analysis highlights the limitations of the model, such as its accuracy being below the satisfactory range for distances d≤50m. 

We developed a joint communication and radar for automotive systems. The hardware system utilizes the 76- 77GHz and 77-81GHz bands reserved for automotive radar to exchange data between vehicles in addition to performing radar functions. The OFDM-based joint radar and communication system has been configured to meet the classification performance levels for Short Range and Long Range sensing. The system has been shown to deliver between 446-1440Mbps data rate based on different deployment scenarios without sacrificing radar performance. This is the first radar-communication system developed for automotive radar systems that can achieve these data rates.

The received power in Vehicle-to-Barrier (V2B) communications is modeled as a function of various factors such as the distance, angle and height of the vehicle and barrier antennas. A multivariate regression scheme is used to model the received power, which includes the impact of directional antenna angle and vehicular body attenuation. The model takes into account diffraction and reflection from the barrier surface. The deviation between the model and empirical measurements is analyzed as a log-normal random fading component. The statistical analysis of the model supports that the deviation of empirical data and data derived from the model supports the hypothesis of Gaussian distribution. The P- value for all the crash tests is ≥0.87 with a 95% confidence interval. The received power model is robust and can predict received power for the V2B crash test scenario with RMS error ranging from 3.65dB to 8.23dB for directional barrier antennas. The OFDM data processing scheme has been improved for symbol-level processing, generating 25 data points per frame.

Previous experiments targeted the 5GHz band for DSRC standard. In light of high-frequency solutions for high-throughput vehicular communications, the channel properties in this spectrum are investigated. Extensive experiments were performed in various locations to support mobile connectivity capabilities.

A fully connected deep neural network is designed to estimate received signals using information such as distance, antenna angle, antenna height, vehicle velocity, vehicle type, barrier type, and antenna type. This model introduces a complete data-driven scheme to predict received power for the V2B network based on these mentioned parameters. The deep learning-based received power prediction has an overall 2.65dB RMS error. This is around 5.5dB lower than our previous least-square multivariate linear regression approach.

This project offers students hands-on experience in vehicular safety and crash data analysis by working with MwRSF during real crash experiments. Students gain an understanding of roadside barrier systems and use high-precision sensors to measure displacement and velocity.

Our research projects, including V2B communications, were presented at a UNL research program for Senator Deb Fischer and NU President Carter and Chancellor Green. Collaborative relationships with traffic and government agencies have been established to install, monitor and evaluate prototype devices and communication techniques.

Information from extensive experiments during vehicle crash tests and the associated code is made available to the public to support reproducible research. The associated resources (design, code, data) for the solutions and their evaluations have been stored following our data management plan. They are publicly shared on our software and datasets page (https://cpn.unl.edu/software-and-datasets) and the project page (https://cpn.unl.edu/projects/v2b) upon publication of research results.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2023
Modified by: Mehmet C Vuran
